Draught at Casa Verde, 5/24/17.Clear, blonde-maize-golden body with a hint of ruddy orange and a medium-sized, white head that fades quickly to cover. Little bit of chill haze, but clear, for the most part.Esters rise up quickly and initially it¬ís very yeast-driven and fruity. Not overly sharp, anyways and not mixing with alcohol. Light juiciness in the form of kumquat, nectarine and ripe apricot with a bit of spicy pineapple perking things up considerably. Not intensely aromatic, but what¬ís there is quite nice (it was also served in a shaker at a Mexican restaurant). Clean.Very fruity in flavor, as well; tons of juicy yellow fruits with a prominent, fresh pineapple-like character. Good maltiness to the texture and quite dry, as Pipeworks is, thankfully. Honey from the malt balances pretty easily. Bitterness lingers on the finish and turns a touch piney and astringent with a bit of alcohol/sharp ester in the mix. Other than that, this is quite nice. Reminds me quite a bit of Zombie Dust, though not as intensely aromatic and clean and crisp as that one.

Got in a trade with The-Adjunct-Hippie. 16 ounce can into pint glass, canned on 9/12/2016. Pours slightly hazy golden/straw color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense and fluffy white head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of tangerine, lemon, grapefruit, pineapple, peach, passion fruit, mango, melon, white grape, blueberry, light pepper/pine, cracker, bread, light honey, herbal, and floral/grassy earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of bright citrus/tropical hops and moderate pale malt notes; with god strength. Taste of big tangerine, lemon, grapefruit, pineapple, peach, passion fruit, mango, melon, white grape, blueberry, light pepper/pine, cracker, bread, light honey, herbal, and floral/grassy earthiness. Light-moderate pine/herbal/spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of tangerine, lemon, grapefruit, pineapple, peach, passion fruit, mango, melon, berry, citrus peel, pepper, pine, cracker, bread, and herbal/floral/grassy earthiness on the finish for a while. Fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of bright citrus/tropical hops and moderate pale malt flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance, and zero lingering hop astringency after the finish. Light-moderate dryness from bitterness, increasing through the glass. Medium carbonation and light-medium body; with a very smooth, fairly crisp/grainy/sticky, and lightly resinous balanced mouthfeel that is awesome. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 6%. Overall this is an outstanding pale ale! All around awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of bright citrus/tropical hops and moderate pale malt flavors; very smooth, crisp, and refreshing to drink. Very bright on hop flavors; great malt balance, without feeling heavy or sweet. A highly enjoyable offering.

4 pack of cans from Peak Liquor. Packaged on November 16, 2016. It¬ís a pretty clear beer with just a touch of hop haze in the body. Golden in color and with clingy lacing on the glass. Aroma is very fresh, genuine, and assertive. Notes of grapefruit, papaya, orange are here. The body is full enough, but dry and crisp. Not a whole lot of malt character, maybe slightly nutty and bready, hard to tell through the giant hop flavor. Caramel does finally become tastefully apparent halfway through. The finish really brings out some marmalade while grapefruit and tropical fruit notes are persistent. Just a great beer all around. I¬ím not buying the American pale ale nomenclature, though. It¬ís got way too much hop character and decent alcohol heft to not be an IPA.

text: Hops and Hocks, Brooklyn can: Pours golden with a white head. Aroma is tropical fruit, like pineapple and melon and stuff. Taste is not too bitter with great fruity character. Similar to the non-bitter breed of IPAs that are all the rage with the kids these days. Very tasty.

Similar flavor, moderate hop bitterness balanced by a light malt sweetness. Medium body with a grainy finish. Refreshing and easy to drink, a pleasant pale ale overall.

Tallboy at home, less than 2 weeks old. Pour is hazy golden with a moderate-sized head and decent lacing. Big pineapple, melon skin, cantaloupe, light grassy hops, mango, and mandarins in the aroma. Taste is clean - nice pineapple, melon, papaya, some lemons, light grass, oranges, and tangerines with a crisp-light bitter finish. Full moutheel with sharp carbonation. Crisp and refreshing with great fruit flavors. Highly crushable stuff.

Poured from a can. 
Aroma is hop forward with juicy mango, papaya, melon, tropical fruit and light citrus. Some light stone fruit notes with hints of dank notes. Medium light cracker malt notes. 
Pours a hazy, dull, yellow gold with a medium sized, thick white head that slowly recedes to a thin film that lingers. Medium lacing and small legs. 
Flavor has a medium light sweetness with light cracker malt notes that linger a bit in the finish. Lots of tropical fruit hop flavors with mango, papaya and lighter melon and citrus. Moderate bitterness. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, a nice pale ale with light malt notes that work well with the tropical fruit character of the mosaic hops. Bitterness is moderate and there is a nice, dry finish.

The beer pours pale yellow with a mild haze and a white head. The aroma has a bunch of tropical hops, heavy on pineapple, pale malt and some grapefruit. It has a medium/light body with some smoothness and moderate amount of carbonation. The flavor starts with pineapple, smooth citrus, pale malt, dryness and some spice. The finish has more spice and some mango. Quite tasty.
16 ounce can from Binnys Champaign. Pours a nice color. Big nose and taste of tropical fruit, pineapple. Really well done.
Can. Pours golden with thin white head. Aroma is fruity mango passion fruit tangerine. Taste is fruity passion fruit and tangerine with a hoppy piney grapefruit finish. Very good.
Can - Pours yellow white head - nose/taste of citrus, green onion, fresh and canned pineapple, orange peel - medium body.

Slightly hazy golden pour. Outstanding head volume, world class lacing and retention.

World class nose of grapefruit, mango, pineapple and a touch of spicy spruce over a biscuit base.

Light medium body that is quite smooth in texture and has a touch of oily character. World class carbonation with a nice effervescent middle and a finely bubbled prickly finish. 

The flavor profile is quite outstanding. It begins with mosaic hops. The flavors of the nose are there in a blended fashion, but pine/spruce dominates the profile. Grapefruit arrives after the burst of pine/spruce then slowly the tropicals emerge underneath. The middle brings a balanced bitterness that is a blend of grapefruit rind and spruce. As the rind fades a bit, a slightly sweet (biscuit) orange note is there. The finish is a slow fade of light rind bitterness.

From a tall boy, pours a slightly hazy yellow with a white head. The smell is tart fruit, tropical and citrus. The taste is citrus, melon ending dry and crisp. Light in body with average carbonation level and structure. Very drinkable stuff!

Nice alternative to my usual train beer which Daisy Cutter.

Draft on tap at Binnmys Lincoln Park Tasting Room (Chicago, IL). Excited to try an Pipeworks beer with a real ABV. Pours a gently hazed golden amber hue, a gentle dulled fiery glow throughout with subtle haze, frothy whitish head atop stays as a decent ringer, frothy filmy layer with good lacing offered. Aromas show some distinct tropical fruit and kiwi, touches of citrus, florals. Firmer hop slant but not overly resinous, a good cool fruity
vibe grows with grapefruit, guava and tropical elements hitting well. Some bread, cereal grains and florals. Initial is lighter end of the fold in body, cleaner fermentation allows some decent citric and bitter hops to show up. Kiwi, guava and touches of lemon hit the palate. Some gentle florals grow quickly, firmer bitterness rolling into the backend and finish, dank diesel, citric and fruity bitterness grow. A gentle spice, cleaner body really let¬ís these hops triumph, firm Mosaic and some dank hoppy tropical slants take but don¬ít really offer the girth and potency I was expecting. More dank diesel mixes with guava and Mosaic. Finish is bitter, a bit dank and earthy. Decent florals, earth. The hop profile here seems a bit off, I dig the flavors but then it doesn¬ít necessarily follow through for my own tastes as we finish up, diesel laden and dank. While I think the malt base is a killer, mellow and clean offering the hops offer some potency and juicy life up front and trail off a bit as we start to move on. Gets a bit messy back there. Still a very nice offering, a bit soapy and floral. Solid offering, would like to see them narrow in the hops before canning.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2015 Draft. Hops are oily and diesel heavy. Malt bill is very simple, seemingly 2row and some crystal malt but very pale and more in the hop water type of beer. I didn¬ít find this beer bitter enough for the alcohol and sweetness level but that¬ís just me - An APA at IPA strength that wasn¬ít very balanced. So clear and crisp. Fermentation was super clean. Just doesn¬ít smell or taste particularly good. Mosaic Promise destroys this. Hopefully they can do some tweaking before this hits canning production. Or not, everyone¬ís going to love it either way.  3.3

Can, the hop use seems to have been tweaked and it¬ís a much smoother / cleaner mosaic character, balance is there now as it doesn¬ít seem too sweet at all. However, the mosaic character has a good dose of that diesel thingy, bit oniony as well, all contributing to a dirty/astringent finish which was the main problem with the draft/beta version. Another issue I have with it still is a personal thing that I don¬ít care for hop water beers. The mosaic hop is so load that it needs balance with a richer base malt. Hence why mosaic promise is so good and is a character you can¬ít get with generic 2 row malts. 3.4
